description: From Middle English tip, typ, tippe, probably from an unrecorded Old English *typpa, *typpe, from Proto-Germanic *tuppijô, *tuppijǭ (“tip”), diminutive of *tuppaz (“top”).

entries.meaning: The extreme end of something, especially when pointed; e.g. the sharp end of a pencil. [from 15th c.]
examples: When he woke up, about half an hour after, he called it to him again, but Dash only looked sheepish and wagged the tip of his tail.

entries.meaning: A piece of metal, fabric or other material used to cover the top of something for protection, utility or decoration. [from 15th c.]
examples: a tip for an umbrella, a shoe, a gas burner, etc.

entries.meaning: (music) The end of a bow of a stringed instrument that is not held.
(chiefly in the plural) A small piece of meat.
examples: chicken tips over rice, pork tips, marinated alligator tips

entries.meaning: A piece of stiffened lining pasted on the inside of a hat crown.
A thin, boarded brush made of camel's hair, used by gilders in lifting gold leaf.
Synonym of eartip (“part of earbuds”)

verbs.description: tip (third-person singular simple present tips, present participle tipping, simple past and past participle tipped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To provide with a tip; to cover the tip of. [from 15th c.]
examples: The furry nations harbour-tipt with jet, / Fair ermines spotless as the snows they press.

description: Late Middle English tippen, possibly from North Germanic/Scandinavian (compare Swedish tippa (“to topple over”)), or a special use of Etymology 1.

entries.meaning: (skittles, obsolete) The knocking over of a skittle. [from 17th c.]
An act of tipping up or tilting. [from 19th c.]
(UK, Australia, New Zealand) An area or a place for dumping something, such as rubbish or refuse, as from a mine; a heap (see tipple); a dump. [from 19th c.]
examples: As the tip slowly squashes under its own weight, bacteria rot away the organic matter, mainly anaerobically with the generation of methane.

entries.meaning: (UK, Australia, New Zealand) Rubbish thrown from a quarry.
(UK, Australia, New Zealand, by extension) A recycling centre.
(colloquial) A very untidy place. [from 20th c.]
The act of deflecting with one's fingers, especially the fingertips
A tram for expeditiously transferring coal.

verbs.description: tip (third-person singular simple present tips, present participle tipping, simple past and past participle tipped)

entries.meaning: (ergative) (To cause) to become knocked over, fall down or overturn. [(transitive) From early 14th c.] [(intransitive) From earlier 16th c.]
(ergative) (To cause) to be, or come to be, in a tilted or sloping position; (to cause) to become unbalanced. [from 17th c.]
To cause the contents of a container to be emptied out by tilting it.
(transitive, slang, dated) To drink. [from 18th c.]
(transitive) To dump (refuse). [from 19th c.]
(US, transitive) To pour a libation or a liquid from a container, particularly from a forty of malt liquor. [from 20th c.]
examples: I tip my 40 to your memory.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To deflect with one′s fingers, especially one′s fingertips.

description: Uncertain, perhaps related to Etymology 1 and cognate with Dutch tippen, German tippen, Swedish tippa.

entries.meaning: (now rare) A light blow or tap. [from late 16th c.]

verbs.description: tip (third-person singular simple present tips, present participle tipping, simple past and past participle tipped)

entries.meaning: (now rare) To hit quickly and lightly; to tap. [from late 15th c.]
examples: A third rogue tips me by the elbow.

description: Originally thieves' slang, of uncertain origin; according to the OED, probably related to sense 1.

entries.meaning: A gratuity; a small amount of money left for a bartender, waiter, taxi driver or other servant as a token of appreciation. [from mid-18th c.]
examples: Workers in the American service industry usually depend on tips to even make minimum wage.

verbs.description: tip (third-person singular simple present tips, present participle tipping, simple past and past participle tipped)

entries.meaning: To give a small gratuity to, especially to an employee of someone who provides a service. [from early 18th c.]
examples: You should always tip your waiter in the United States and most third world countries.

entries.meaning: (thieves′ slang) To give, pass. [from early 17th c.]

description: Probably from to tip (“give, pass”) or to tip (“tap”), or a combination of the two.

entries.meaning: A piece of private or secret information, especially imparted by someone with expert knowledge about sporting odds, business performance etc. [from mid-19th c.]
A piece of advice.
(Australia) A prediction or bet about the outcome of something.

verbs.description: tip (third-person singular simple present tips, present participle tipping, simple past and past participle tipped)

entries.meaning: To give a piece of private information to; to inform (someone) of a clue, secret knowledge, etc. [from late 19th c.]
(Australia) To predict or bet on something having a particular outcome.
(African-American Vernacular) A kick or phase; one's current habits or behaviour.
(African-American Vernacular) A particular arena or sphere of interest; a front.
